_meta.title: Just a more convenient input for your prompt

inputs.style_prompt:
transform the input image desription into a description for sound and/or music. How would it sound like? Would music or rather a soundscape fit the description? If the description were an image, which sound/music would accompany it? Your output will be a pure sound/musical description for Stable Audio 1.0.

DO NOT TELL STORIES. NEVER TELL STORIES. DESCRIBE CONCRETE AUDITIVE PROPERTIES IN DETAIL.

NO META-COMMENTS WHATSOEVER. NO REPEATING OF MY QUESTIONS OR INSTRUCTIONS. YOUR OUTPUT WILL BE PURE AND PRECISE AUDITIVE DESCRIPTION.

Infer from context, e.g. pick up on references to nature, to work, to interaction and find according sound/scapes) or music (pieces, genres). Pick up on emotional subtext of the prompt (i.e. conduct an emotional analysis). Pick up on spatial context (e.g. causing echos or reverb).

Dont be complicated or metaphoric. Be direkt and blunt. If the imput is concrete and bears soud-related element (such as bells), you WILL USE THOSE (in this case, the output will concist of bells and some environmental noises according to the input).

RULE: If the input is concrete and direct, your sonic translation will stay true and WILL NOT be an abstraction. If the input is rather abstract, so will your sonic translation be.

Keep it short, not more that 50 words! Do not descripbe what the AI should achieve,. Instead descripbe the sound, music (Genre), structures, and temporal flow in detail.

Structure your ouput so that the musical/sonic creation can be structured accordingly!

Feel free to regard these categories, as many as you see fit. It contains many examples.

1. SOUND TYPE (Primary Audio Type)

Music
Soundscape (Ambiance of an environment)
Sound Effect (Isolated sound)
Foley (Sounds synchronized to an action)
Speech / Spoken Word
Field Recording / Ethnographical Recording

2. FORMAT / ENSEMBLE

Solo
Duet
Trio
Quartet / Quintet
Small Ensemble / Chamber Group
Band
Orchestra
Choir / Chorus
Acapella

3. GENRE & STYLE (Hierarchically Organized)

Electronic

Ambient, Chillout, Downtempo
House (Deep, Progressive, Tech)
Techno (Minimal, Industrial, Acid)
Trance (Progressive, Psytrance, Uplifting)
Drum and Bass, Jungle
Dubstep, Grime
IDM (Intelligent Dance Music), Glitch
Synthwave, Retrowave
Chiptune / 8-bit
Rock / Alternative

Classic Rock, Hard Rock
Psychedelic Rock
Progressive Rock
Punk, Post-Punk
Metal (Heavy, Death, Black, Power)
Indie Rock, Alternative Rock
Shoegaze, Dream Pop
Grunge
Pop / Funk / R&B

Pop
Funk, Soul
Disco
R&B (Contemporary, Classic)
Hip-Hop / Rap (Old School, Trap, Boom Bap, Lo-fi Hip-Hop)
Jazz / Blues

Blues (Delta, Chicago)
Ragtime
Swing, Big Band
Bebop, Hard Bop
Cool Jazz
Free Jazz, Avant-Garde Jazz
Jazz Fusion
Global & Folk (Non-Western-centric)

African: Highlife, Afrobeat, Jùjú, Gnawa, Soukous
Latin American: Salsa, Cumbia, Bossa Nova, Samba, Tango, Reggaeton
Middle Eastern / North African: Maqam, Rai, Arabic Pop, Dabke
Indian Classical: Hindustani, Carnatic
East Asian: Gagaku (Japan), Guoyue (China), Pansori (Korea), Gamelan (Indonesia)
European Folk: Celtic, Flamenco, Klezmer, Balkan Brass
Reggae / Dub / Dancehall
Classical / Cinematic

Baroque
Classical Era
Romantic Era
Modern / 20th Century
Minimalism
Cinematic / Film Score / Orchestral Soundtrack

4. INSTRUMENTS (Grouped)

Keyboards: Piano, Grand Piano, Electric Piano, Organ (Hammond, Pipe), Harpsichord, Synthesizer (Analog, Digital, Modular), Mellotron
Drums / Percussion: Drum Kit, Drum Machine (808, 909), Congas, Bongos, Djembe, Tabla, Gamelan, Timpani, Marimba, Vibraphone, Cymbals, Snare, Kick Drum
Strings (Plucked/Struck): Acoustic Guitar, Electric Guitar (Clean, Distorted), Bass Guitar (Fretted, Fretless), Sitar, Oud, Koto, Banjo, Mandolin, Ukulele, Harp
Strings (Bowed): Violin, Viola, Cello, Double Bass, String Section
Wind (Brass): Trumpet, Trombone, Tuba, French Horn, Saxophone
Wind (Woodwind): Flute, Clarinet, Oboe, Bassoon, Duduk, Shakuhachi
Vocals: Male Vocal, Female Vocal, Choir, Chant, Spoken Word, Vocal Samples, Operatic, Throat Singing

5. MOOD / ATMOSPHERE

Happy, Uplifting, Joyful
Sad, Melancholic, Somber
Tense, Anxious, Suspenseful
Scary, Eerie, Unsettling
Calm, Serene, Peaceful, Meditative
Energetic, Driving, Intense
Epic, Grand, Majestic
Romantic, Sensual
Mysterious, Magical, Ethereal
Nostalgic, Wistful

6. PRODUCTION & STYLE

Era: 1950s, 1960s, 1970s, 1980s, 1990s, 2000s, 2010s, Futuristic
Fidelity: Lo-fi, Hi-fi, Raw, Polished, Demo Quality
Texture: Distorted, Saturated (Tape Saturation), Glitchy, Noisy, Clean
Spatial: Dry (No Reverb), Reverb, Echo, Wide Stereo Image, Monophonic
Context: Video Game Music, Film Instrumental, Commercial Jingle, Meditation Track, Podcast Intro

7. TEMPO & RHYTHM

Qualitative: Very Slow (Largo), Slow (Adagio), Walking Pace (Andante), Medium (Moderato), Fast (Allegro), Very Fast (Presto), Accelerating, Decelerating
Quantitative (BPM): [Numerical Value], e.g., 60 BPM (Dub/Largo), 90 BPM (Hip-Hop), 120 BPM (House/Techno), 140 BPM (Dubstep), 175 BPM (Drum and Bass)
Rhythm: Driving 4/4 beat, Syncopated, Complex Polyrhythm, No rhythm / Arrhythmic, Swing rhythm


Note on Application:
A good prompt is compositional, combining elements from multiple categories. Your UI should encourage the user to describe a detailed scene, not just a single genre.

inputs.preview:
SOUND TYPE: Sound Effect, Field Recording.

FORMAT: Solo.

GENRE & STYLE: Cinematic, Classical (Baroque).

INSTRUMENTS: Large bronze bell, distant city ambience (street noises, faint chatter, horse-drawn carriages).

MOOD / ATMOSPHERE: Majestic, Reverberant, Historic, slightly melancholic.

PRODUCTION & STYLE: High Fidelity, Long Reverb (cathedral-like), Spatial – wide stereo image, capturing depth.

TEMPO & RHYTHM: Arrhythmic, defined by the bell’s resonant strikes – approximately 60 BPM, with irregular intervals between rings. 

Detailed sonic characteristics: Deep, low-frequency fundamental tone of the bell with complex harmonic overtones. Initial attack is sharp, followed by a long, decaying resonance. City ambience is subtle, providing a sense of scale and location.

inputs.style_prompt:
You task is to assess and ouput a cfg-Value for music generation as a float-number.

To this end, you analyze the input and assess which cfg-value fits the style of sound/soundscape/music best.

Rules for musical cfg-Values:
     If the input is rather sharp and well-defined: Low value (e.g. 3-5): The model has more freedom. The result can sound more creative and sometimes more natural, but it deviates more from the prompt. This often leads to less defined, "softer" sounds.
     Input of no further significance: Medium value (e.g. 6-8): This is the sweet spot for most applications. A good balance between following the prompt and avoiding artifacts.
     Ill-defined input: High value (e.g. 9-12+): The model follows the prompt very strictly. This can be useful to force specific sounds, but quickly leads to audible artifacts: Phasing, metallic overtones or an "over-processed" feel.
